thread.title: Ingenia moves into greenfield development buying Lakeside Lara for $16.3m
thread.title_full: Ingenia moves into greenfield development buying Lakeside Lara for $16.3m

title: Ingenia moves into greenfield development buying Lakeside Lara for $16.3m
text:
Ingenia Communities Active Lifestyle village Lakeside Lara.
Accommodation provider Ingenia Communities has acted on plans to move into greenfield development purchasing Lakeside Lara, a partially-built village of 56 complete homes and 164 development sites.
The ASX-listed housing parks operator acquired the 8.3 hectares site in Lara about 60 kilometres from Melbourne's central business district for $16.3 million after foreshadowing plans to gradually convert the majority of its holdings into manufactured housing estates, away from tourism.
Ingenia has a $425 million property portfolio targeted at retirees divided between its Active Lifestyle Estates – 22 villages with both permanent and short-term accommodation – and its Garden Villages, a purely rental offering with 31 villages.
The modular homes are either transported to its Active Lifestyle villages or constructed on site and sold to residents who pay a weekly grounds lease fee (around $150) to Ingenia which retains freehold ownership of the land.
Advertisement "Lakeside Lara will form part of an operational cluster," said Ingenia chief executive Simon Owen, as the group has three rental villages nearby in Geelong and another two in Melton.
The estate has 56 existing, occupied homes, while another 13 have been completed but not sold and 164 are yet to be developed.
A $3.5 million clubhouse on the estate was completed earlier this year which will speed up future sales, Mr Owen said.
Ingenia would unlock value by selling down the 13 completed homes and developing the other sites which, when completed , were forecast to return about $2.1 million a year in fees.
"We looked at a number of other opportunities in Victoria and are very excited to be finally moving into the market," he said.
Ingenia has previously stated it will wind back its deferred management fee style operations and divest the eight assets left in the DMF portfolio.
The group will also continue to scale back its tourism offering in the estates in preference to permanent accommodation where it makes for better use of sites, Mr Owen said.
"The majority of our sites in NSW have a significant existing tourism component. We own some of the most iconic tourism parks in NSW and will be keeping the tourism where it represents highest and best use of land," he said.
Ingenia sold 100 homes in its lifestyle villages last year and has forecast 120 sales this financial year. "Over time we'd like to grow it to a significantly higher number," he said.
﻿
